title: selkirk-gallery-strikes-gold-new-exhibition
story: A BORDERS-based artist is bringing some Byzantine influence to a small museum in Selkirk.From next month gold will dominate Halliwells House as Alexandra Warren launches her exhibition in the Robson Gallery.Born in New York and raised in Greece, Alexandra developed a love of Cycladic sculpture and Byzantine icons.And despite spending the past  years in the Scottish Borders her work is still heavily influenced by the continuation of the Roman Empire.Her magnicent human figures and extensive use of gold leaf reflect a letimes influence.Alexandra told us: ldquoIrsquom very happy and honoured to have the opportunity of a solo exhibition in the lovely Robson Gallery in the historic Halliwellrsquos House, Selkirk.ldquoIrsquoll be presenting large figurative pieces and a series of small figurative paintings."Each piece is created with gold leaf, paint and shellac on wood , all inspired by Greek Byzantine icons - since I was lucky enough to have spent my childhood in Greece.rsquorsquoThe Traces of Gold exhibition opens on Saturday, March  and runs until the end of May.Assistant curator Phoebe Stewart said: ldquoWersquore delighted that Alexandra Warren is exhibiting with us in the Robson Gallery at Halliwellrsquos House."Her exquisite work, reminiscent of Greek Byzantine art, is a must-see."

title: tenants-help-shape-eildons-new-green-housing-revolution
story: LOCAL social landlord, Eildon Housing, has confirmed work will begin next month on a further  new family homes in the Borders.And they hope research from their green-building revolution will lead to even better eco-friendly homes in the future.With the completion of three Passivhaus houses at Springfield Place in St Boswells over the next few weeks, attentions will turn to a similar -house development in Westruther.Two families from each development will provide regular feedback regarding their new homes.And the findings will help shape future projects.Nile Istephan, chief executive of Eildon, believes there is high demand for the eco-friendly three- and two-bedroom properties.He said: "Built to Passivhaus standard, the homes generally need  percent less energy for heating and hot water than standard buildings with very low running costs."This is another stride towards our fight against fuel poverty."Westruther is one of four developments forming Eildonrsquos green pilot which will see up to  new green homes built using dferent building methods."Working in partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Construction Scotland Innovation Centre and Glasgow School of Art the pilot will compare construction costs, time to build and the experience of tenants living in the homes."The Westruther homes are expected to ready for new tenants by the spring of .Mr Istephan added: "We will be looking to work closely with two families at each of the green projects to for a period of time when they move in."The results will be used to determine not only the future building programme for Eildon, but also lead the way for how Scottish homes are built and lived in, in the future. "

title: thought-provoking-exhibition-brings-borders-history-life
story: AN exhibit at Hawick Museum is showcasing the work of three local artists who were inspired by artefacts held by the museum.With the rural Borders at the heart of this exhibit, Liz Douglas, Felicity Bristow, and Jenny Pope each created their interpretations of ious items in the museums collection.Liz Douglass contribution was inspired by a shepherds lantern from the th century from the Live Borders archive and her wider work has been influenced by the thirteen drty days of .Jenny Popes work is more sculptural, using materials such as porcelain, felt, and paper and testing their usage limits.She was inspired by the Poachers Riddle from the museums Domestic Room to create tools with new s.Her portrayal of items which appear weathered "to suggest the uncertainty and changes we all face as human beings".Fellow sculptor, Felicity Bristow, was also inspired by items found in the Domestic Room, with her work looking to create pauses which calm the body and mind after being physically and mentally lsquofloodedrsquo by natural, physical and emotional external sources.Richard White, Assistant Curator at Hawick Museum, said: "We are delighted to have these artists exhibiting in our newly refurbished Scott Gallery."This is an interesting exhibition which is sure to make people think."As a charity, Live Borders aims to make people healthier, happier and stronger and visiting this exhibition should certainly help make people happier."Tools for Survival: A Conversation Between Three Artists runs until  March  in the Scott Gallery at Hawick Museum. Opening times: Monday to Friday : to :, Sunday : to :. Closed Saturdays.Admission is free and donations are welcome.

title: across-pyrenees-melrose
story: NEXT SundayMelrose Music Society continues its concert season with Across the Pyrenees: French and Spanish Music for the Saxophone.The concert, generously sponsored by the Tunnell Trust, will give the audience an exciting and colourful exploration of the cultural sympathy and musical styles of the two countries on either side of the Pyrenees.Saxophonist Jonathan Radford studied at Cheethamrsquos School of Music and the Conservatoire National Supeacuterieur de Musique de Paris with Claude Delangle, graduating in  with a Masters Degrees with distinction in both saxophone and chamber music.Pianist Eleanor Kornas, from Derbyshire, graduated with a First Class Honours Music degree from Cambridge University, and she was an Adami Award Junior Fellow in Piano Accompaniment at the Royal College of Music. She now works as a Staff Accompanist at Cheethamrsquos School of Music having performed as a soloist and accompanist both in the UK and internationally.The French side of their programme includes works by Milhaud, Caplet, Lauba, Faureacute, Maurice and Borne, the last piece a lsquoFantasiersquo based on melodies taken from Bizetrsquos Carmen opera. The Spanish side is represented by music of Manuel de Falla and Pedro Iturralde.The concert starts at .pm at Melrose Parish Church Hall.Tickets, priced at pound and free for accompanied school-age children, are available at the door.

title: remember-galashiels-1970
story: MEMBERS of a Galashiels history group are inviting you to take a walk down memory lane from next month.The latest Old Gala Club exhibition relives .From a year of long-hair, flares, Apollo  and the Beatles disbanding, the club members have brought together a fascinating exhibition of le in Galashiels.The exhibition at Old Gala House, showcases photographs from their extensive collection along with toys, records, sports memorabilia, stamps, pre-decimal coins and even a vintage chemistry set.Murray Dickson, president of the Old Gala Club, told us: ldquoWe always enjoy working in partnership with Live Borders on our annual exhibition at Old Gala House."This year we are rolling back  years to  and, using photographs and objects from our archives and collections, we hope to give townsfolk and visitors a flavour of what le was like then.The Galashiels in the s exhibition will run from Saturday, March  through until October  in the Museum Room at Old Gala House.Phoebe Stewart, assistant curator at Old Gala House said: ldquoWersquore delighted that The Old Gala Club is exhibiting with us for the season."It will be a fascinating trip back through the years to see what Galashiels was like."

title: famously-hawick-set-tour
story: A PROJECT to promote Hawick has just launched an imaginative range of guided tours.Famously Hawick wants to provide visitors with an experience of the towns rich manufacturing heritage.And they hope the new all-year-round tours will demonstrate why Hawick gained an international reputation for producing high quality goods.These new lsquoexperience packagesrsquo are the latest development from the collaboration of premium producers in the town.Successfully launched last year, Famously Hawick promotes The Borders Distillery, Hawico, Johnstons of Elgin, William Lockie and Lovat Mill as the Cashmere, Tweed and Whisky town.But based on feedback, visitors didnt want to just buy the quality goods, they wanted to see where they came from and how they were made.As a result, Famously Hawick tour packages have been created.There are three dferent experience packages available - An Introduction to Famously Hawick, which is an independently led tour, The Famously Hawick Experience, which is a fully guided tour including lunch, and the Famously Hawick Gold Standard, which is a fully bespoke tour.The tours can be booked online at www.famouslyhawick

title: council-spend-730k-new-hq-canteen-reception
story: COUNCILLORS are set to rubber-stamp spending more than pound, on creating a new reception and canteen at their headquarters.As part of the forthcoming years budget proposals, pound, has been earmarked for the building with a further pound, to be spent on demolition of the old canteen.The proposals are part of the planned   capital spend.A spokesman told us: "The existing staff canteen building at Scottish Borders Council headquarters, which also contains meeting rooms and storage, is le expired."The council is establishing a lsquograb and gorsquo facility as part of improvement works to the public reception area of the main headquarters building."This will enable the canteen building to be demolished, delivering savings in respect of rates, maintenance, lighting and heating.

title: jim-clark-driving-trail-cover-scenic-borders
story: A CROSS-BORDERS driving trail has been created for visitors wanting to learn more about rallying icon, Jim Clark.The -mile adventure trail will take drivers on a tour of the Borders with pit-stops showcasing regional beauty spots as well as locations steeped in motorsport history.Launched by the Jim Clark Trust, the trail hopes to engage visitors and help them discover the places and stories behind the former double Formula One Champion, Clark.The trail starts and ends at the Jim Clark Motorsport Museum, Duns, and is completely free of charge as it is designed to enhance the experience had at the museum.From the museum, a trail map guides visitors to Chirnside, Jim Clarks hometown and final resting place, then to Berwick-Upon-Tweed where Jim began his racing career. After crossing back into the Borders over the Union Chain Bridge, towards Winfield Airfield, home of the first Scottish Motor Racing Meeting.And before the final stop back at the Museum, the last featured destination is the Charterhall Airfield, where Jim saw his first Scottish motor race. Motorists can then refuel at the Jim Clark Cafeacute Bistro.Ben Smith, chair of the Jim Clark Trust told us: ldquoThe Jim Clark Motorsport Museum is fast becoming a magnet for classic and sports car enthusiasts."The Jim Clark Trail is an exciting new adventure for all visitors, on a far more modest scale to the North Coast , a stunning driving tour celebrating the rich heritage and culture of the Borders.Jim Clark was a world-renowned racer, having won the Formula One World Championship in  and , as well as the Indianapolis  in . At heart he was a Borders farmer, working on his familys farm at Edington Mains.Sir Jackie Stewart OBE, Honorary President of the Trust, recalled: ldquoHe was the best."Shy almost introverted, modest, he was a Borders farmer after all. And he never stopped being a Borders farmer.The trail map not only guides visitors to locations in the history of Jim Clark, but prompts tourists to visit other Borders market towns such as Coldstream, Kelso and Jedburgh.The Jim Clark Trust have also collaborated with Scottish Borders Council, Live Borders, and the Midlothian Borders Tourist Group to support local tourism and businesses. They are encouraging local businesses to get in contact to help develop the trail further.Any businesses wishing to join the trail should contact the Trust at info@jimclarktrust.The Jim Clark Motorsport Museum will open for its new season on Sunday, March . For more information, visit www.jimclarktrust.

title: silent-disco-set-mac-return
story: FOLLOWING last years sell-out club night, silent disco is set for ato the Mac Arts.More than  head-phoned revellers enjoyed the two silent sessions in Galashiels in November.And just as many are expected when Silent Knightsnext month.Rikki Toner from Silent Knight said: "At a silent disco instead of loud music participants will be given headphones and music will be transmitted to everyone wearing the headsets."To those watching it appears to be a room dancing to no music."Silent Knights will host an afternoon family silent disco, between pm and pm.And then its the over s only from pm to midnight.There will be three dferent music channels to choose from at each disco.Rikki added: "The family event will feature a channel of Top  pop, dance-along favourites and a channel of classics for the parents."The evening adult event will see three live DJs playing simultaneously with guests able to flick between the DJs, with several genres and eras of music covering the three channels."The silent discos will take place on Saturday, March .Tickets, priced at pound for the family event and pound pound for the evening disco, are available from www.macarts.scot

title: gallery-grand-opening-dream-come-true-owner-artist
story: AN Innerleithen gallery is set to officially launch in the town next month, supporting the career dreams of its owner and the launchs featured artist.Kate Hayes opened Solo Gallery, which sits at  High Street, Innerleithen, in December , but the gallerys official launch will be held on Saturday, March  and will highlight the work of landscape artist, Louise Turnbull.Kate moved to Galashiels in  after working in business, and began plans for Solo Gallery in the summer of .She told us: "Moving to the Borders and opening a gallery has been a real change of pace for me, but the chance to show the work of new and established artists to potential buyers is a real joy."Im delighted that Louise will be the featured artist at the gallery opening - her work is full of emotion."Louise Turnbull swapped a career in learning and development for one in art in , and moved to Walkerburn where she had her own studio space and access to the Tweed Valley for inspiration.She said: "Im loving my new le as a professional artist and I hope I can inspire a few more people to follow their dreams."Im delighted that Im able to show off my latest work at Solo Gallery and its exciting to know that Kate has brought a great new gallery to my doorstep."Solo Gallery will officially open on Saturday, March , between pm and pm.

title: students-delight-cashmere-panel-scarf-designs
story: A PARTNERSHIP between a Galashiels cashmere company and secondary schools across the Borders has led to some eye-catching designs.And,youre lucky, you could be wearing one of them round your neck next winter.In conjunction with Developing Young Workforce Borders and Heriot-Watt University, third-year pupils at four dferent schools took part in the Sinclair Duncan scarf design competition.And the expert  were blown away during the day of presentations.Alistair McDade, business development director at Sinclair Duncan, told us: "The standard of all the designs was extremely high."Each team had approached the project in a dferent way and it made our job as lists very dficult."Itrsquos been fantastic to witness the students from Heriot Watt guide the pupils in creating a design concept and translating it into a woven product."Since September teams from Berwickshire High, Galashiels Academy, Jedburgh Grammar and Earlston High, along with their Heriot-Watt University student mentors, have learned about market research and product marketing, taken part in design workshops, enjoyed mill tours and Computer-Aided Design experience, and honed their presentation skills.And last week the design students from all four schools went head-to-head at the Sinclair Duncan studio.The judging  was tasked with choosing a design to be made into a cashmere scarf for sale at Abbotsford Visitor Centre.And a second design also had to be selected to be turned into a sash for presentation to the Best Dressed at Kelso Races Ladies Day in May.Following y deliberation, Earlston High was announced the Abbotsford winner.Tania Murray from the Abbotsford Trust said: "We are very much looking forward to seeing this beautul design as a cashmere scarf."The inspiration, which was lsquoAbbotsford at nightrsquo is very fitting."The team will also be involved in creating a display for the scarf within the shop so they have to think about the full journey of designing, manufacturing and selling a product."Jedburgh Grammars Eildon@Ladies Day design was selected for the Kelso Races winners sash.Further awards were presented to Galashiels Academy, who received the Sinclair Duncan Award for design Excellence, exhibiting the strongest skills in design research and application of technical knowledge.And Berwickshire High School was awarded the Developing Young Workforce Award for work-skills excellence.Sara Ward from Developing Young Workforce commented: "It was great to see this team embrace the project fully and demonstrate such strong links between their learning and skills required for the workplace."Manufacturing starts straight away and the finished scarves will be on the shelves towards the end of May.All of the teams will be presented with a limited edition scarf made from their winning designs.They will also be on display at The Borders Textile Towerhouse in Hawick.

title: cops-search-attempted-parcel-snatcher-galashiels
story: POLICE are appealing for help following an attempted parcel snatch in Galashiels on Saturday morning.The delivery driver managed to fight off the masked thug at around .am in Beech Avenue.Officers believe a second man nearby was an accomplice.And they are appealing for help to catch the two men.Detective Constable Narelle Allan said: ldquoThis incident has left the victim understandably shaken and he managed to hold on to the parcel that the suspect tried to take from him which is now undergoing further investigation.ldquoWersquore eager to hear from anyone who may have been in the Beech Avenue area of Galashiels on Saturday morning and who witnessed what happened, or any suspicious behaviour or iniduals in the vicinity beforehand.ldquoEqually anyone with any information to assist our inquiries is urged to come forward.The attempted thief was wearing a black balaclava, grey trousers and a black hoodie.Anyone with information should call Police Scotland on .

title: reston-station-plans-submitted
story: HOPES have been raised this week of another train station being created in the Borders.For over a decade campaigners have been calling for an East Coast Mainline stop at Reston in Berwickshire.The Scottish Government has included a new station in its spending plans for the next five years.And this week Network Rail tabled a screening request to Scottish Borders Councils planning department.The outline plans for a new Reston Station include -metre s either side of the Berwick-to-Edinburgh line as well as a footbridge, shelters and a -space car park.The plans will be considered over the coming weeks by planning officials.

title: shook-finger-clickin-good

Selkirk Musical Theatre Companys stunning adaptation of the Joe DiPietro theatre play will have Souters creating new Spoty playlists for months to come.But its not just the terric versions of the songs that make this hilarious, hip-swinging show such a success.The Selkirk cast, whose numbers have swollen in recent years, is stronger now than it has ever been.And its the confidence and title: politicians-clash-finances-new-peebles-high
story: A FRESH row has erupted over the finances required for a new Peebles High School.Local Conservative council leader Shona Haslam and the local authoritys education portfolio holder Carol Hamilton hit out earlier this month at what they claimed was a financial snub from the Scottish Government.Their claims infuriated Deputy First Minister John Swinney, who reiterated Holyroods commitment to help following the school fire in November.But last weeks budget announcement by the Conservative Independent administration has now sparked a fresh row.According to the figures presented a new Peebles High will cost around pound million - with only pound million coming from an insurance settlement.The claim that there will be a pound million deficit has led to MSP Christine Grahame seeking clarication.The councils chief finance officer David Robertson has confirmed that Peebles High has an insurance value of pound million.And that the local authority is working with loss adjuster appointed by Zurich on a final settlement - expected to be made next month.But the correspondence has now thrown up more questions, with Ms Grahame demanding to know where a pound million deficit will occur.She told us: "The claims being made by Councillor Haslam and her Tory colleagues are going to be massively concerning for the school community."As soon as the scale of the damage from the fire was apparent I wrote to SBC to check that insurance would cover the cost of rebuilding ndash I was told yes, it should.ldquoCllr Haslam has already been caught in one lie by saying the Scottish Government has refused funding for the rebuild when SBC have never requested it. And why would itit was covered by insurance ldquoIs it the case that the insurance company has rejected a claim for new build and will pay only for reinstatement of the damaged areas  If that is the case then she should come clean. She is claiming the school faces a pound million deficit."The only explanation I can offer is that this is the cost of replacement of damaged areas but on this Ms Haslam is silent.ldquoI await her response, but in the interim I would ask her seriously to desist in trying to play politics with this to get a disingenuous hit on the Scottish Government and SNP."It serves no one and is unnecessarily causing genuine concern amongst the local community when efforts should be going into ing stability and normality to students, parents and staff.Scottish Borders Councils administration has committed to delivering replacement secondary schools in Galashiels, Hawick and Peebles in the next six years.Councillor Haslam believes that an improved replacement school for Peebles school along with using parts of the remaining building needs to be factored in to the calculations.In a response to Christine Grahame, she said: "As you are well aware the insurance will only pay to replace what was lost."This will still result in a music department in a windowless basement and a science department in labs that are not fit for purpose."Despite this our school continues to produce first class scientists and musicians but I believe they deserve more and better."We had planned to replace Peebles High School in the next  years. To only do part of the school now would be a  economy and impact on future plans to replace outdated buildings."I know how keen you are to see a new High School delivered in Galashiels so am perplexed as to why you are so against Peebles getting the same facilities  Perhaps you could clary  I am certainly not satisfied with half measures for our young people."We are also extremely keen to ensure that other towns developments are not held back as a result of this fire. So Galashiels and Hawick remain on schedule to be delivered. This means that our Conservative led council will be delivering three new High schools, two new primary schools in the next six years, quite an achievement as I am sure you will agree."This is held against the backdrop of a cut to our capital budget this year of  percent."

title: former-melrose-winger-backs-murrayfield-abseil
story: A SUPERHERO abseil down the Murrayfield stands has been supported by two Scottish rugby legends.Former Melrose player, Craig Joiner, and Edinburgh attack coach, Duncan Hodge have both backed the superhero feat in aid of Scotlands Charity Air Ambulance .Craig said: "SCAA is Scotlands only charity-funded helicopter air ambulance and without the support of people such as these abseilers we wouldnt have this vital resource."None of us knows when we might need the service and everyone who joins in this fun event at BT Murrayfield should be very proud of their efforts."Duncan added: "Its rare to get the opportunity to abseil from the stands on to the pitch at BT Murrayfield."So not only are these fundraisers supporting a great cause, theyre among a very select group of people to add this achievement to their le story."The abseil, which is set to take place on Thursday, March , is looking for volunteers to raise at least pound each for the charity before taking part in the Murrayfield touchdown.The  foot drop from the top stands will be where the superheroes take off from, and friends and family come come along to support the abseilers as they descend.Regional fundraising manager for SCAA, Carol Ann McMahon, said: "SCAAs own heroes are on call every day of the year to fly expert paramedic care to the most sick and injured in our communities and airlt them to advanced hospital care."Every superhero who takes on the BT Murrayfield abseil will help ensure this amazing charity stays in the air for those most in need across Scotland and our many islands."Borderers who feel up to the super challenge can sign up at https:murrayfieldabseil.eventbrite and pay a pound registration fee.

title: tesco-slash-1-800-jobs-bakeries-overhaul
story: MORE than , jobs are at risk atTesco ndash as part of changes to bakeries in its stores.The supermarket giant, which has a store in Galashiels, has announced , members of staff will be made redundant from May across the country.Tesco will then stop baking bread from scratch in  of its shops.In  stores, only the most popular products will continue to be baked from scratch on site.But the locations of the job losses have not yet been revealed.Jason Tarry, the companys CEO, said: "We need to adapt to changing customer demand and tastes for bakery products so that we continue to offer customers a market-leading bakery range in store."We know this will be very dficult for colleagues who are impacted, and our priority is to support them through this process."We hope that many will choose to stay with us in alternative roles."

title: brushing-regions-biggest-ever-art-fair
story: MANY of the regions leading painters and sculptors are brushing up ahead of the biggest arts fair ever held in the Borders.Around  artists, galleries and collectives from the region and beyond visual culture."Wersquore greatly looking forward to building on the success of last yearrsquos Borders Art Fair and to delighting and inspiring visitors from across Scotland and the rest of the title: emergency-work-begin-scotlands-first-wallace-statue
story: SCOTLANDS first-ever monument to William Wallace is to be saved.Concern has been raised about cracks appearing in the -foot statue which overlooks the Tweed near St Boswells.And fears were growing for the future of the -year-old iconic sculpture.But the few remaining Trustees of the statue have arranged for emergency work to be carried out in April.And it is hoped that a fundraising drive through the summer will lead to further preservation work to prevent any more deterioration.Jesse Rae, who is one of the William Wallace Trustees, told us: "Emergency repairs will be made to the plinth this spring."I was up at the statue last summer with friends and I noticed there was damage beginning to appear."When I went back up a few months ago it was looking in a sad way."We know what needs to be done and well make a start with the repairs to the plinth in April."William Wallaces role in Scotlands history was brought to a world-wide audience by the film Braveheart.But the th century freedom fighter, who was proclaimedof Scotland in Selkirk, had been revered at home for centuries before the Mel Gibson movie.In  David Stuart Erskine, the th Earl of Buchan, commissioned the statue for a site overlooking the Tweed.Although the likeness to Wallace is questionable, and the style of sculpture has a decisive effect on opinion, the statue has and continues to attract visitors to the Borders.Isabel Hay from the William Wallace Society believes more should be done to protect the monument.She said: "I am concerned about the disrepair of the statue."It hasnt been looked after and its in the public interest for this tribute to William Wallace to be saved."We as a Society want to help preserve the Wallace monument and make sure its condition doesnt get any worse."The Saltire Society raised pound, back in  for the monument to be repaired and ed to its original state.And around a decade later the locally-based William Wallace Trustees raised enough money to improve the car park and access path to the statue.But weathering has led to fresh problems with the stonework.Musician Jesse, who made a fundraising song for the statue in the late s, hopes to announce new trustees to look after the statue in the coming weeks as well as plans, which include promotions through a television station, to raise funds for a second phase of preservation works.He added: "Many of the original Trustees are no longer with us but we have people lined up."The second phase of works will include the Claymore - we need to get the emergency repairs done first."

title: community-given-reassurance-ahead-melrose-sevens

title: senseless-vandals-hurl-bottles-nursery-window

title: msp-riverside-medical-practice-cannot-expand-boundary-issues-fixed
story: Colin Beattie MSP said this decision followed talks with Jeane Freeman MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport.Last year, the Primary Care Contractor Organisation outlined plans to alter the practice boundary to take patients from the Blindwells new town development.Construction is set to get under way on the first of the , phase one homes at the former opencast mine site between Prestonpans and Longniddry.Over the next decade and beyond, up to , new homes and community facilities are expected to be built there.Also proposed is a ldquoLevenhall Queen Margaret University extension as part of the boundary change at the Riverside GP practice.The practice is based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre , along with Inveresk Medical Practice, which is separate.After it merged with Eskbridge Medical Practice, Riverside became the largest practice in East Lothian and one of the biggest in Scotland, with about , patients.Mr Beattie said: ldquoFrom correspondence with local constituents, it was clear to me that action needed to be taken to remedy the ongoing issues in relation to Riverside Medical Practice.ldquoI have spoken with Jeane Freeman, the Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport, who is now working closely with NHS Lothian to ensure that a solution is found.ldquoIt was decided that the best route forward was to allow no further boundary expansions of the practice until the service is ing at a satisfactory standard.ldquoI am sure that this decision will be welcomed by all those who have concerns about the practice.He added: ldquoOf course, the NHS does not have complete control over the operations of the practice, given that the doctors are simply contracted by the NHS to run this service. However, NHS Lothian will work closely with the management going forward to ensure their budget is managed more effectively, and that the issues at hand are adequately addressed.Members of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council have also told health bosses that the proposed boundary expansion would be ldquoa step in the wrong direction.The group contacted the Primary Care Contractor of East Lothian Integration Joint Board.The community councillors highlighted complaints they had received from members of the community, including:A statement issued by the community council practice acknowledged the fact that they had undergone many changes in the last few years, not least the fact that they are on their third telephone system.ldquoThe practice also stated they will need and this will enable the staff to put you on to the right person who can help and this could be NHS , paramedics, physio, mental health or occupational therapistor alternatively, a doctornecessary on the same day.Wrong direction ldquoWe discussed the boundaries and made them aware that we felt that to take on Blindwells would be a step in the wrong direction.ldquoThe meeting was quite positive and hopefully, moving forward, we will keep in touch with the practice and they with us so that everyone is kept informed.Dr Stenke and Dr Fairclough issued a joint statement, saying: ldquoWe were delighted to meet with the Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council representatives and local councillors. We felt it was a really positive opportunity to discuss many of the changes that have happened in Musselburgh over the last few years to stabilise and develop primary care services.ldquoIt is really important for us at Riverside to understand the views of the community we serve, which can be hugely supportive in improving services. For example, feedback on our old phone system helped us to understand the issues that our patients were experiencing and led to us developing a new telephone system that was more suitable for our patientsrsquo needs as well as those of the practice.ldquoRiverside, along with other practices in the county, are collaborating with and supporting East Lothianrsquos Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos plan to grow health services to meet the needs of a growing population.ldquoWe remain keen to improve our engagement and communication with the local community, and the meeting was a positive step to build links with local groups.ldquoWe are grateful to the community council representatives and local councillors for taking the time to visit us at Riverside Medical Practice and we look forward to developing a closer and collaborative relationship with them.An East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership spokesperson said: ldquoWe thought the meeting with Riverside and the community council was very positive. We look forward to supporting them in any way that we can.Councillor Mackie added: ldquoIt was a helpful meeting with community stakeholders and local GPs. title: tims-tales-gift-magic-space
story: A STORYTELLER friend recently gted us an articial electric log stove and hearth surround with mantle piece.She is an expert at recycling, and placed it where the real fireplace used to be and it looks fantastic. When the fire effect is switched on, it gives an impressive imitation of a real one.Our small terraced house once had a real fire place, of course, but like so many it was modernised before I moved in, and it was filled in and central heating installed.Yet I am old enough to have lived all my childhood in the lsquos and lsquos without experiencing central heating! It did exist, of course, just not in the houses I lived in as a child!One memory I have is of arriving home from school on a cold winterrsquos afternoon and seeing the smoke coming from the chimney of the church house we lived in at the east end of the Pans. My father had lit the fire early and I still remember its welcoming warmth, and the way it crackled and danced as it defrosted my face and hands. Me and my brothers sat by it, jostling for the best space.Donrsquot get me wrong, Irsquom not complaining about central heating! I know Irsquom lucky to have a warm house and never take it for granted. We donrsquot use the lsquofirersquo for heat, that would be too expensive. But we switch it on for atmosphere. And the effect on the younger kids has been immediate. They sit by it, lie on blankets by it reading and playing and telling stories. I forget that they have little personal experience of having a hearth, even an articial one. The novelty will wane, perhaps, but I hope the cosy pleasure of it wonrsquot.Itrsquos not just the kids, as my we and I love sitting by it in the evening. Wersquove even moved some of the furniture, so this pretend but convincing fireplace, rather than the telly, has become the main focal point of the living room.You could say Irsquom easily pleased, and I suppose thatrsquos true. But our friends have commented on it too, one saying ldquoit really has given your house a dferent atmosphere as he sat by it with the wind howling outside.The hearth has traditionally been the soul of a house. The family would sit by it, soak in the warmth and watch the flames, while telling stories and talking. It was a draw for social communion. Visitors would be welcomed with a place by it and most of the cooking would have taken place there too. The old saying ldquolang may yer lums reekindicated the importance of a lit hearth as a symbol of wellbeing and good fortune.No wonder so many traditions and ceremonies were centred around the hearth. People used to leave objects buried within or near it. There were ious reasons for this: to capture bad spirits that may come down the chimney, for good luck or to deflect a witchrsquos spell. The hearth was seen as a kind of spiritual portal, to be defended and made safe, not just physically.The hearth was also a focus of many ceremonies that marked the changing seasons. The Celtic calendar is full of such events, Imbolc being the most recent. And of course there were the daily rituals of banking up the fire at night, and reviving it in the morning, and keeping it going. All these simple tasks are now fast fading into folk memory.Today, screens are more likely to be the focal point of our homes. Itrsquos kind of unavoidable, of course, and I claim no moral high ground of this issue. But the truth is they drug our senses and dull our conviviality, and, like many parents, we have tried to limit their use in our house. It has felt like a losing battle with my children who, I understand, live in a very dferent childhood to mine. And I readily concede itrsquos got lots of benefits, even though at times I may sound like an old dinosaur lamenting the passing of the Jurassic age.But the arrival of our fake woodburning stove has transformed our house in a way that shows we have lost something in the lsquomodernisingrsquo of our homes. As a storyteller, I have come to understand the importance of a hearth as a focal point for gathering it has the power to bring people together, to share warmth and light but also each otherrsquos presence and social connection. As the freezing wind rages outside, it is a magical space.That magic has been the true gt from my storyteller friend, and she wisely knew it. While much is missing from an articial fire, including the smell and sound of the real thing, our ancestral instinct still kicks in by the visual sight of a flickering hearth.So now my instructions to switch off the screens is more readily obeyed, because it signals time to get together around the fire and lsquobe together properlyrsquo to tell stories and challenge each other with riddles.Burnrsquos poem The Cotterrsquos Saturday Night now has new meaning in our house:To meet their dad, wi flichterin noise and glee.His wee bit ingle, blinkin bonilie,His clean hearth-stane, his thrty wiersquos smile,The lisping infant, prattling on his knee,Does arsquo his weary kiaugh and care beguile,An makes him quite forget his labor and his toil.

title: waterside-bistro-chief-takes-castle-inn-dirleton

title: bench-put-place-memory-tranent-legend-bobby-marr
story: Bobby Marr, who ran a greengrocer and florist on Tranentrsquos Winton Place for nearly  years, passed away last July.The -year-old was a familiar face to many in Tranent town centre, with hundreds attending his funeral.Marion Hoggan was heavily involved in the fundraising for the bench for Mr Marr, who had colon cancer.She said: ldquoI did not manage the funeral due to work commitments and I felt that I wanted to do something for him. I came up with the idea of the bench and spoke to the family and they were quite keen on it.ldquoMyself and a couple of friends did a fundraising day at the Store Club on January .ldquoIt was a sell-out ndash it sold out within a week of talking about it ndash and a lot of people did not get tickets.ldquoDavid Martin was the host and we had Derryn McKillop, Jim McCran, Donna Howe, Jack Robertson, Dean Jones and Mags Foster there.ldquoThey all entertained us all day, free of charge, and gave up their precious time.In total, the event raised more than pound,, with any money above the cost of the bench being donated to the oncology department at the Western General Hospital in Edinburgh.Mrs Hoggan described Mr Marr, who lived on the townrsquos Kennedy Crescent, as ldquovery kind and ldquoa true gentleman and said he always took an interest in the bowling exploits of her daughters Kim and Dee.She thanked local businesses and shopkeepers for the donation of raffle prizes and cash donations for the fundraiser last month.She also paid tribute to David Forrest and Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council for working alongside East Lothian Council to see the bench put in place.Mr Forrest, chairman of the townrsquos community council, was also among those at the unveiling ceremony off the townrsquos High Street.He said: ldquoI remember Bobby Marr in his shop and I remember when his parents owned it. I was at school with Bobbyrsquos older brother and Bobby was always a nice bloke, always friendly and always helpful.ldquoThe shop has been part of Tranent for as long as I have been in Tranent.More than  people turned out off Tranent High Street at the war memorial on Tuesday afternoon for the unveiling of the bench.Councillor Kenny McLeod, who lives in the town, was among those at the short ceremony, which took place on what would have been Mr Marrrsquos th birthday.Mr McLeod was delighted with the event and felt it was a fitting gesture.He said: ldquoThere was a big turnout of about  folk.

title: chance-look-plans-new-houses-cemetery-dunbar
story: Planning permission for a residential development and cemetery for land at Newtonlees, to the east of the town, was given in .Detailed plans for the housing scheme on the site were submitted to East Lothian Council in August .Now, following discussions with planners, Robertson Homes has submitted revised proposals, which members of the public will get the chance to see on Tuesday between pm and pm.John Murphy, managing director, Robertson Homes, said: ldquoWe are extremely pleased to bring forward our revised plans for Newtonlees in Dunbar following positive discussions with the council.ldquoThe revised layout has taken into consideration some of the points that were raised with us by the council and local community groups.ldquoFollowing submission, we are keen to meet with members of the public and local interested stakeholders to receive further feedback.ldquoAs such we are hosting an open day on Tuesday at our Fair Acres development showhome in Dunbar to showcase our revised proposals and update the community.ldquoWe would welcome as many local interested parties as possible to pop in and see us.The site will be made up of three, four and five-bedroom homes, with  per cent allocated for affordable housing.If planning permission is granted, it will also enable the development of a new cemetery to include , lairs,  ashes-only lairs and an area of woodland burial.The original plans, which looked at the possibility of a cemetery and housing development, went before the local authorityrsquos planning committee.Controversially, the plans, which were submitted by Gladman Developments Ltd, were approved, despite being outwith the councilrsquos Local Development Plan.The plans went to a vote, with Dunbar and East Linton ward member Councillor Norman Hampshire, who is convenor of the planning committee, given the deciding vote.Mr Murphy highlighted how the development would benefit local businesses.He said: ldquoWe are committed to the East Lothian area and have plans to set up a designated east of Scotland business ision.ldquoWe currently have around  members of our workforce from East Lothian, including a site and construction manager who are local.ldquoIn addition, we also contract with six local businesses on our projects in East Lothian.

title: calls-made-properly-surface-muddy-quagmire-path
story: People walking from the Robertson Homes site, off Bowmont Terrace, towards Spott Road have to pass under the East Coast Main Line.While the majority of the path is either tarred or gravelled, there is a small section under the railway bridge which is yet to be surfaced in a suitable manner.Iain McDonald, who lives on the townrsquos Dempster Place, was among those frustrated about the small section of path, which became unusable after wet weather.He said: ldquoThe problem is the path directly under the bridge is still a farm track, and with the prolonged rain it has become a muddy quagmire. It is impassable for wheelchair users.More than  new homes are being built at the site off Bowmont Terrace, with a further  given planning permission for a second site, which will also include a new cemetery for the town.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed the ground under that the railway belonged to Network Rail.She said: ldquoThe housebuilders developers have the responsibility for this path but the ground under the bridge is Network Rail and we understand that they are in discussions to arrange dates for this work to be carried out.Network Rail was approached for a comment but did not respond.
